review.title: Phishing Detection in IMs using Domain Ontology and CBA - An innovative Rule Generation Approach
review.abstract: User ignorance towards the use of communication services like Instant Messengers, emails, websites, social networks etc. is becoming the biggest advantage for phishers. It is required to create technical awareness in users by educating them to create a phishing detection application which would generate phishing alerts for the user so that phishing messages are not ignored. The lack of basic security features to detect and prevent phishing has had a profound effect on the IM clients, as they lose their faith in e-banking and e-commerce transactions, which will have a disastrous impact on the corporate and banking sectors and businesses which rely heavily on the internet. Very little research contributions were available in for phishing detection in Instant messengers. A context based, dynamic and intelligent phishing detection methodology in IMs is proposed, to analyze and detect phishing in Instant Messages with relevance to domain ontology (OBIE) and utilizes the Classification based on Association (CBA) for generating phishing rules and alerting the victims. A PDS Monitoring system algorithm is used to identify the phishing activity during exchange of messages in IMs, with high ratio of precision and recall. The results have shown improvement by the increased percentage of precision and recall when compared to the existing methods.

sections.text: The architecture of the PDS Monitoring System consists of the following subsystems: • Instant Messaging System with client and web browser. • PDS Monitoring System using OBIE and CBA. • Database (Message DB, Filter word DB, Ontology DB, Phishing rules DB and Phishword DB) Figure 1 shows the architecture of the PDS Monitoring System in the Instant Messaging System (IMS), with the interaction between different subsystems to recognize the phishing words by the context of the instant message and to the victim clients.The architectural subsystems of the PDS Monitoring System as described in the following subsections:

sections.heading: 3.5 The OBIE Architecture
sections.text: In order to determine the domain and context of the instant message using the Ontology Based Information Extraction (OBIE) component of the PDS monitoring system, information extraction must be converted into a machine-comprehensible form. This OBIE module first reads the keywords of the instant message stored in the Word DB (FWDB) filter. The concept of the semantic lexicon is used to identify the semantic domain and the context for the keywords processed by the domain inference module. Here, the triplet algorithms are used to help identify the theme concept and the domain in the inference module [12]. Instance information is extracted through the instance extractor module. An RDF node is created and the ontology is updated using the Jena Apache APIs. Existing ontology editors such as the Ontology Extractor module can be used for editing the lexology.

sections.heading: 5. RESULTS AND OBSERVATIONS
sections.text: Sample ScreenshotFigure 4 Screenshot Chat Session 1 with Phishing AlertsPerformanceThe contextual PDS monitoring system was tested on 110 transactions between chatters using domain ontology and improved rules generated by CBA to detect phishing words and generate ALERTS for the victim. The performance of the classifier is usually measured on the basis of accuracy, the percentage of correct predictions over the total number of predictions made. Precision and recall are used for this: Precision = true positives / (true positives + false positives), i.e. the number of correctly predicted false swears. The total number of true positives (correctly identified phishing words) obtained from 110 transactions was 97. The number of false positives (phishing words + false negatives) detected incorrectly turned out to be false.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Instant Messaging Systems (IMS) are generally unable to detect many fraudulent phishing attacks, making them vulnerable to cyber scams. To overcome this, a framework for dynamic detection of phishing attacks in instant messaging messages is proposed, using the rules of the Classification Based Association and domain ontology. APDS monitors the psychology of the user and predicts the type of phishing activity detected with a warning to the victim client.

sections.heading: 6.1 Future Work
sections.text: English is not the only means of communication on a subcontinent like India, it could be multilingual, the concept of translating and applying phishing detection is a future challenge. Words from other languages could be written in English that no ontology-based tool can identify and ignore, which in turn could prove to be a phishing attempt. Images, sounds and videos are the formats that require a lot of work, except text formats where the vulnerability to phishing can always be present. The following issues and challenges are therefore identified that many research activities should focus on. • Definitive phishing messages are sent in any other format as text formats (images, audio, video), then they are not recognized. • The rules lack multilingual support for fraudulent phishing detection. • Problems with interpreting a message written in multiple languages.
